Posts.Content: Hi. My father (he's 69 years old) was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. In August 2017, PSA was around 4 (had been around this level for the past few years). In March 2018, PSA was 6. Then he did MRI scan, which suggested the likelihood of cancer. In April 2018, he did MRI-Ultrasound fusion biopsy. The biopsy took 6 cores from right side (Systematic Right Prostate Biopsy), 6 cores from left side (Systematic Left Prostate Biopsy), and 14 cores from other regions (ROI Prostate Biopsy). The result: -One out of 6 right sided cores contain Gleason 3+3 (ISUP Grade 1/5) adenocarcinoma in less than 5% of the core. No perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension is seen. -4 out of 6 left sided cores contain Gleason 3+4 (ISUP Grade 2/5) adenocarcinoma in between 5% and 80% of the core. No perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension is seen. -Other cores show no atypia or malignancy. The urologist suggested that surgery to remove the prostate is the best. But for the surgery, he needs 'clearance' from my father's cardiologist. My father doesn't feel any heart-related problems but he has been routinely seeing a cardiologist to monitor his heart. Based on some tests and scans (which we don't completely understand), his cardiologist has always suggested him to do angiogram but my father always resisted because he feels fine. So regarding the prostate surgery, his cardiologist wants to do angiogram first, before he can give 'clearance'. There's a possibility that angioplasty (installing stents) would be done. If angioplasty does happen, my father needs to take blood thinners non-stop for 3 to 6 months. Thus this scenario would delay the prostate removal surgery for at least 3 to 6 months. The urologist then said that waiting for that length of time is okay and he did not give any medication to take for now. In cases similar like my father's, is it generally okay to delay the surgery for 6 months? And during those 6 months is it generally better to have some medication to 'fight' the cancer? Thanks.
Posts.Signature: My father is 69 years old, as of early 2018. In August 2017, PSA was around 4 (had been around this level for the past 2 years). In March 2018, PSA was 6. MRI Scan in April 2018 suggested likelihood of prostate cancer. MRI - Ultrasound fusion guided biopsy in April 2018. 26 prostate tissue samples were taken. One core (out of 6 right-sided prostate cores) contains Gleason pattern 3+3 (ISUP grade 1/5) adenocarcinoma in less than 5% of the core. Four cores (out of 6 left-sided prostate cores) contain Gleason pattern 3+4 (ISUP grade 2/5) adenocarcinoma in between 5% and 80% of the core. Other cores show no atypia or malignancy.
Posts.Title: Should we delay the surgery?

Posts.Content: Hi, My father was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. I wrote the history in my signature. I've got some questions. In the MRI result, one of the conclusion is "No MRI features of overt extracapsular disease extension or seminal vesicle invasion. No pelvic adenopathy detected bilaterally." And, in the biopsy report, it says "No perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension is seen". Thus, can we conclude that the cancer has not spread beyond the prostate? If this has not been conclusive/definite, will doing a PET Scan give a definite answer? We're very thankful for forums like this and this forum has certainly helped a lot of people and will continue to do so. Thanks everyone

MRI Scan in April 2018 suggested likelihood of prostate cancer. MRI - Ultrasound fusion guided biopsy in April 2018. 26 prostate tissue samples were taken. One core (out of 6 right-sided prostate cores) contains Gleason pattern 3+3 (ISUP grade 1/5) adenocarcinoma in less than 5% of the core. Four cores (out of 6 left-sided prostate cores) contain Gleason pattern 3+4 (ISUP grade 2/5) adenocarcinoma in between 5% and 80% of the core. Other cores show no atypia or malignancy.
